characters: A CONVOY OF SQUADRA MOBILE VEHICLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets of Rome are locked in a 3AM traffic jam. MUSI spills from cafes and discotheques. We DESCEND further...

dialogues.speaker: TITLE UP
dialogues.text: ...into sidewalks overflowing with prostitutes, B-movie s mafiosi, down-on-their-luck royalty and paparazzi darting between cars on Vespa scooters. And now, from out of the crowd, something even stranger emerges:

dialogues.speaker: A BOY
dialogues.text: in his mid-teens, at once streetwise and innocent. A skin kid in worn jeans with iron-on patches on the knees. The streetwalkers in their platform shoes call out to him:

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTES
dialogues.text: Ciao, Paolo! The kid smiles bashfully as they fall in around him.

dialogues.speaker: PROSTITUTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Che magro, che vergogna! So skinny. Paolo, bambino, why don't you let us make you breakfast? We'd look after you real nice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (smiles, blushing) I bet you would. A car pulls up to the curb: it's time for the girls to go back to work. Maria-Donna pulls Paul close, serious now:

dialogues.speaker: MARIA-DONNA
dialogues.text: Hurry home, Paolo, eh? The street is no place for a boy like you. Don't make your poor mamma worry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself. Ciao, Maria-Donna. Paul walks on, leaving the girls to haggle with their joh He pulls out a folded-over issue of Fantastic Comics and walks away into the darkened, narrow Via dei Bauillari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flicker to life behind him. Paul walks on, oblivious, immersed in his comic book. The car creeps forward. The headlights like owl's-eyes. A white Fiat 600. It drives up behind him. Hovering. A man climbs out. He wears a red ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: SKI MASK
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah -- ? Paul turns and sees them. A moment -- and then he runs. In an instant, they are upon him. The boy flails, kicking and writhing to buck them off. He's got a lot of fight in him for such a skinny kid; it's as if he knew this was co They open the trunk and shove Paul inside. He doesn't fit Someone sits down on the trunk. The latch clicks: it's closed. The men pull off their mas Their eyes are black and wild with adrenaline. They climb into the car.

dialogues.speaker: SKI MASK
dialogues.text: Avanti! Go!

dialogues.speaker: A PHONE RECEIVER
dialogues.text: clatters into its cradle. We TILT UP to reveal a flustere young SECRETARY in red lipstick and a tight sweater. She rises from her desk, overwhelmed, and she begins to run.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE, (SURREY, ENGLAND)
dialogues.text: A sprawling 400-year-old mansioned estate surrounded by gardens and statuary. The secretary runs across the grounds in her high heels. She runs past a row of ancient busts of Roman emperors. She runs past a full-grown male LION pacing in a gilded c She runs past a swimming pool ringed by lounging STARLETS She trips and stumbles as she breaks a heel. She reaches down, pulls her shoes off, and runs in her nylons --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- up the stairs of the mansion, past walls cluttered wit vast art collection. She runs down the hallway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and opens the door to a huge room, empty but for a Lou XIV desk, a phone and an old-time paper-tape stock ticker A man in a bespoke suit stands at the window, gazing out upon his estate. The paper tape from the stock ticker sna across the room and through his fingertips. He whispers price quotes to himself, like a monk saying the rosary.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr Getty. I should have knocked but -- it's -- J. PAUL GETTY turns and cocks an eyebrow. His gaze is qui and focused; he has the impatience of a man whose mind is always sixty seconds ahead of whomever he's listening to.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: To the point, Nancy, the market's open.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: They've -- He's been kidnapped! Paul, Little Paul, your grandson, in Rome my God he's just a child -- The ticker-tape in Getty's hands stops moving.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They need to speak with you, it's very urgent. The Italian police, the boy's mother, they're on the phone right now. A tremor of emotion in Getty's eyes. Then it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I'm not available. The Secretary stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Getty?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: The door, Nancy. She closes the door as the tape in the Getty's fingertips starts to move again. We hear young Paul in VOICE-OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be a Getty is an extraordinary thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Fiat 600 (with Paul in the trunk) drives throu a toll gate and onto the great Italian highway.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know that because my grandpa told me so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J Paul Getty and the young Paul walk down a dark tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You're a Getty, Paul. A Getty is special. A Getty has a destiny. A Getty is nobody's fool. The boy gazes up at his grandfather reverently.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You see, my grandpa wasn't just the richest man in the world. He was the richest man in the history of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAND DUNES undulate endlessly unto the horizon. We SOAR OVER THEM until we find a singular figure standing amidst the shifting sands: J Paul Getty.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My grandpa was the one who brought the oil out of the Saudi desert. Everybody knew it was there, they just thought it couldn't be done. We CRANE over the dunes to REVEAL a great city of refiner and pumping oil derricks belching flame, a mirage seeming summoned forth by Getty's will alone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Grandpa found a way. He made a deal with the Bedouin tribes. But there was so much oil there was no ship big enough to carry it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty supervises construction of a SUPERTANKER, a behemot the size of a skyscraper lying on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my grandfather invented one. He called it the supertanker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we soar over the American intercontinental highway, SE STATIONS materialize out of nowhere, dotting the landscap all bearing the Getty name.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then he built a chain of service stations across America with his name on them. Grandpa controlled every drop of oil, from beneath the earth to the customer's gas tank. (a beat) And he was famous.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBOY MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: In a series of B&W still images accompanying the pages of THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEW -- click click click -- Getty holds forth on his great wealth.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBOY
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty, rumor has it that you are the first man in history with a fortune in excess of one billion dollars. How much money do you have?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I have no idea. If you can count your money, you're not a billionaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Fiat 600 winds along the serpentine Italian highway, its headlights blazing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm telling you this so you can understand the things you're about to see. And maybe you can forgive us. We PULL BACK as the Fiat winds along the autostrada, away from the glowing city, until it vanishes into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's like we're from another planet where the force of gravity is so strong it bends the light. It bends people too. We look like you, but we're not like you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) But we were, once.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL HARRIS GETTY
dialogues.text: lies sleeping in a beauty mask as her three children, PAU (9), MARK (4), and ARIADNE (2) bounce on the bed, clamori for breakfast. Her husband lies beside her. Gail GROANS:

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Too early. The sun's not even up. Back to bed, you little monsters. Little Paul peels back one eye of Gail's mask and lets th sunlight in. She recoils.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You made your point. But no pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS: Gail fixes pancakes for the children and a cu of strong black coffee for herself, cleans up empty wineglasses and ashtrays from the party the night before, downs two aspirin, puts a samba LP on the Hi-Fi, washes u dresses the children, pulls on capris, teases her hair, a does a quick little bossa-nova with the children.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Now, you'll have to amuse yourselves quietly. I have work to do this morning and I am not to be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail works with pastels at an easel, copying from a posed photo of a model in a cocktail dress (the music PLAYS OVE from the previous scene, and throughout this whole sequen It's catalog work, but Gail's got a gift for line and ges she has style. Her kids draw on the floor alongside her, copying everything she does. Little Paul especially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail is on the phone, a utility bill in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Look in your file and you'll find that we've been very good customers of Southern California Edison. We're good people.  7. In the sunlight we can see the words PAST DUE written the

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I have a little boy who's concerned that if the lights aren't on for Christmas Santa might not find his way here. Everything about Gail -- her Seven Sisters accent, her finishing school posture -- reeks of the former debutante

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we could make the minimum payment we wouldn't need an extension. We do want to pay something, though. We notice who the bill is addressed to: JOHN PAUL GETTY,

dialogues.speaker: PHONE REP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tell me, Mrs Getty. What does your husband do?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He's a poet. A good one.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE REP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Any relation to the oil man Getty? She considers her answer carefully.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Distant.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE REP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (laughs) Must be, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail piles all three children into a Ford Fairlane. She holds the electric bill in her hand, along with her drawi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail hands over her drawings. The girl at the desk pays $ apiece, in cash. Gail wouldn't dream of counting the mone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail counts the money. She stuffs it in the tray at the payment window. She thumbs through what's left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail walks through Beverly Hills with her three children tow. She passes a store window and stops. It's Givenchy.  8. She gazes longingly at the window display of a woman in a sapphire evening gown... and then we RACK FOCUS to the mo with three kids reflected in the glass.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are we going home now?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: One last stop, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail approaches the building's registry, with her childre in tow. She steps closer. She takes off her sunglasses. There, encased beneath glass, are the white letters press into black felt: GETTY OIL CORPORATION -- 28TH FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss. May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail and her children stand out on the sidewalk, squintin up at the 20-story glass tower that looms above them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Must be eighty stories at least. How many stories is it, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't know, darling. An awful lot of stories.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What are we looking for, Mom? Gail puts her sunglasses back on.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Your grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: I've never even met the man. JOHN PAUL GETTY II (known in the family as "Big Paul") is young, bearded and handsome, his feet propped up on the w ads on the coffee table before him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know he refused to pay my mother a nickel of child support.  9. Big Paul climbs out of his chair and digs around inside t desk drawers. The apartment is warm, bohemian, filled wit paintings and books and music on the record player.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was a boy, I would send my father letters. "Dear Daddy, how I wish I could meet you. I'1l be waiting for you at the baseball diamond," that sort of thing. (a beat) You know what he sent back? He hands Gail a letter. It's in little-boy handwriting, o lined paper -- but marked up with red ink.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He mailed it back with the spelling corrected. Nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He is your father, that's got to count for something, Paul, the rent is due and Christmas is coming.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: What would you have me do, Gail? Accost him on the street?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We write him a letter and ask for a job. Any job. And this time, we'll get the spelling right. Gail goes to his chair, sits on his lap, and kisses him. looks up at her: she's not an easy woman to say no to.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: You were never meant to be poor, Gail. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We're not poor. We're broke. There's a difference.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: I don't want to be an oil man.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't want you to either. I love you the way you are. All we need is enough to get by, but we're not getting by.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Gail.  10.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm tired of struggling. I'm ready for a different kind of life. Big Paul gets up, picks up the bottle of Chianti from the coffee table, and goes to the bedroom. We HOLD on Gail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail sets her husband's Smith-Corona down on the carpet. She inserts a clean page into the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Dad -- Father -- For years I struggled to understand why you kept your distance. Now I know you were giving me a chance to prove myself, on my own, free from the shadow of your achievements -- no, great -- (backspace, retypes) -- immense achievements. I understand now what a sacrifice that must have been for you. She kneels before the typewriter, a pretty witch conjurin spirits.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Now that I am a man, I have nothing left to prove, except to you. Let me prove myself to you, Father. (a beat) As always, your loving -- no, your loyal son: John Paul Getty Two. She RIPS the page from the carriage and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC. Big Paul reaches into the fridge and pops the top a can of Schlitz. Gail is making dinner on the stove. Big Paul slips his hands beneath her sweater to warm them.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: God, your hands are cold! Stop, the kids are -- I'm serious, you -- Gail wriggles free and Big Paul dances her around the apartment to the BEACH BOYS' CHRISTMAS ALBUM as the child look on. There's a tree with presents beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: (singing along) He's the man with all the toys ...  11. Gail gazes up at him, starry-eyed: for this one moment, a is right with the world. The BUZZER rings.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: That'll be Ms. Canzanelli telling us she's calling the police. (pressing the button) We're so sorry about the noise --

dialogues.speaker: INTERCOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have a car waiting for Mr. John Paul Getty the Second, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: "The Second?" Little Paul goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Down in the street, look -- OUTSIDE, a ROLLS-ROYCE PHANTOM is idling in the street.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Oh my God, somebody died.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: (realizing) No, baby. We've been sent for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As "The Man With All The Toys" continues to play, the lit family rides in the back of the Rolls, along with their hastily-packed bags. The kids exchange a look. Up ahead they see it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LEARJET 23 private plane idling on the runway. The Roll drives right up to the clamshell airstair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Paul wakes up in the back of another limousine. Th other kids gaze amazedly out the window, their breath fog the glass. Reflected in the window is the Roman coliseum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luxurious Roman hotel, with a mustached CONCIERGE waiti to receive them. A BELLMAN takes their bags.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: Signore Getty is awaiting you.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked outside the door is a room-service cart piled high with dirty trays. A "NON DISTURBARE" sign hangs from the doorknob. The Concierge KNOCKS gently. We PUSH into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOTHESLINE is strung across the length of the room, fr which are suspended a line of MEN'S UNDERPANTS on clothes Empty food containers and clothes are everywhere. And everywhere there is art: paintings and artifacts prop against the walls. Little Paul reaches into the mess and pulls out a small statuette lying on the floor: it's a MINOTAUR carved out of marble.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (taking it from him) Don't touch that, sweetheart. Let's just keep our hands to ourselves. It's dirty. (examining it) And old. Possibly priceless.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I deplore that word. They turn to see Getty emerge from the bedroom, freshly groomed and powdered.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Dirty and old I have no problem with at all. In fact I have some affection for them as they're the words most frequently used to describe me, along with rich. Getty goes to the mirror, inserts a tie bar into his coll

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But priceless -- that's another thing entirely. People say priceless when what they really mean to say that something is invaluable, or irreplaceable. That Minotaur statuette in your hands, for instance, dates from 460BC; there are only a handful like it remaining, and none in such pristine condition. I'm sure those fuckers at the Met or the British Museum would kill to get their greasy paws on it.  13.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL
dialogues.text: He just said --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Would you care to guess what I paid for it?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, you're too modest. You've got taste, I can tell. I think you know a good deal about art.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I do. I just don't know what it costs.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Well then, you'll learn. Come on, indulge an old fool. What do you think I paid?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Five hundred thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Eleven dollars and twenty-three cents. I picked it up in the black market in Heraklion. This cripple was asking seventeen dollars for it and it took me an hour to bring him down to his bottom line. At Sotheby's today I'd hazard it'd bring $1.2 million. (a beat) You see, priceless is such an insipid word. Everything has a price. The great struggle in life is coming to grips with what that price is. He crouches down and offers the figurine to Little Paul.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: We couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Do you like it, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's OK. I don't need it.  14.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I insist.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I insist. We can't. It's far too extravagant for a little boy.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: For most little boys, it would be. Getty hands the boy the statue.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But not for a Getty. Little Paul takes the figurine; it's done. They're forced to accept it. Gail and Big Paul smile awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Thank you. We'll treasure it.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Thanks are for strangers. You're family. You're my family. Come here, let me look at you. (brings Big Paul close) Son. My son. My grandson. (to Gail) My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Daughter-in-law, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You're not just some district judge's daughter anymore. You're one of our family now. Getty turns to his son:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had to focus on my mission, you understand. My business. I couldn't be weighed down, mentally, with a family. There was work to be done. You understand that, don't you. Big Paul is silent. Getty darkens, glowering, then walks away, pushing the clothesline aside as he crosses the roo

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pardon the laundry. I wash my undershorts myself, in the bathroom sink. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see no reason to pay ten dollars to have room service launder them when I can do it myself for a few lira. What kind of rube do they take me for? Which reminds me -- He takes out a small notebook and golf pencil and writes entry: LAUNDRY SOAP -- 22 LIRA.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's tax-deductible. Almost everything is, if you know how to play it. What in hell are we doing standing around in this dusty old hotel room? We should be celebrating. That's what families do, right?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After that, everything changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail throws open the windows. The family is moving into a light-filled apartment. Gail is unpacking when she finds

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dad became an executive in Grandpa's company. Mom found us an apartment near the Piazza Navona. -- the Minotaur figurine wrapped in her scarf. It makes h anxious. She finds a shoebox and stashes it in the closet

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And Grandpa started my education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to the SILHOUETTES of Getty and Paul as they wa hand-in-hand through the darkened, ancient tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Come on, I want to show you something. We FOLLOW them through the mouth of the tunnel. They look out upon it: the boy is awed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: It's home. We step out into the sunlight of  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANCIENT ROMAN VILLA in the mountains overlooking Rome, ringed by statues of the Roman gods. Getty leads Paul on house tour:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: This is where I slept with my wife, Sabina. This here is where I ate roast wild boar with my generals. This is where I made love to my concubines. And this is where I took my baths.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You used to live here?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: In the second century, when I was the Emperor Hadrian. I knew it the moment I first visited this place. I remembered every stone as clearly as if I'd just come back from a trip to the store for a pack of smokes. I never felt at home anywhere on Earth until I came here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe they'd let you stay. Overnight, like. Get a tent and a sleeping bag --

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, I tried, believe me. I made them an offer, a very generous offer!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Them?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Rome. The Romans. But when they hear the name Getty they all get dollar signs in their eyes. They said it wasn't for sale.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Figures.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Exactly. That old tactic. That's what I'm talking about, Paul. (a beat) To be a Getty is to have everyone you know secretly want a piece of you. You are surrounded, always, by smiling faces, but you have no one.  17.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You have us.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: (deeply moved) That's true. I have you now. And to think it was almost too late. All I've built would crumble into dust if there's no one to carry it on after I'm gone. (takes Paul's hand) The blood of emperors runs through you, as it does through me. You're a Getty, Paul. You have a destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail, Big Paul and the children descend the gangplank ont 47-foot yacht. Beautiful COUPLES and their children are already relaxing on deck with cocktails and music. ISABEL and JULIAN, the hosts, wave happily as they descend.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Jules, it's the Gettys! (kisses, greetings) We were worried you'd been abducted.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: If I were you I'd make us walk the plank.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Not until we've got a few drinks in you first. And this must be John Paul II?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And III. Charmed LAUGHTER. Big Paul looks a bit taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: No Roman numerals, please. We're American. Just Paul is fine, for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bronzed bodies lie in the sun alongside sweating gin-and- tonics as the yacht glides over a stained-glass sea. Litt Paul tiptoes over and around them -- -- to the bow of the boat, where Gail stands, wearing a w shift dress, her eyes closed: an Aegean goddess. She sees Little Paul, holds out her hand to him, and brings him cl  18.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I feel like we're flying.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Me too, darling. (whispers) The whole world, for you. She hold him as they gaze into the approaching horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty, Little Paul, and Big Paul all sit at the breakfast table, attended by BULLIMORE, a butler in a morning coat. Getty eats a half grapefruit. Big Paul seems hung over. Little Paul eats Cheerios as he reads Getty's mail to him

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: вЂњDear Mr. Getty, I am writing you because we are in desperate straits. My husband suffers from a tumor that has caused his groin area to swell to uncontrollable dimensions. The doctors say without immediate surgery normal movement will soon become impossible. God bless you, you are a Great American, Elvira Broadus, Mound City, Arkansas." Getty dictates as the boy transcribes his response:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Dear Mrs. Broadus, while I am sympathetic to your unique situation, you are one of three thousand people daily who write to me asking for money. If I were to respond to every request for money I receive, I would soon be as destitute as yourself. The boy seems slightly downcast.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yours, JP Getty. Next. The boy places the form letter into an envelope, addresse it, and sets it on a pile of identical letters. Little Pa picks up a new letter and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: вЂњDear Mr. Getty --"

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: Surely you can find someone else to answer your mail.  19.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I like it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: He likes it, son. The boy wants to be useful. I find that admirable. It's a family business. Everyone has a role to play. Which reminds me: I'm firing Howard Larkin. I'm making you Executive Vice President of Getty Oil, with oversight over European operations and exploration.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN PAUL JR
dialogues.text: All I know about oil is regular or unleaded.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You wanted a job. I'm giving you one. Sink or swim. BLACK OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Little Paul's sleeping face. He is older now, al in his teens. His eyes open. He sits up and looks around. We are in a vast room piled with pillows and carpets, and people sleeping upon them. Thick smoke hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul pours a bowl of cereal. There are others here, shirt skinny men with beards and long hair; he doesn't know the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge round bed within a tent-like canopy of brocaded si dominates the room. A man and a woman are sleeping there. Paul lifts the flap of the canopy and climbs into the bed with his cereal. We realize that, beneath the long hair a the beard, the man is Big Paul, his father.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (whispering) Dad. (increasing volume) Dad. Dad. Dad. Big Paul does not move. Little Paul turns and looks at th woman beside him; she is not his mother, but a remarkable dark-haired beauty, a model.  20. Upon the nightstand there's a glass of wine, a lighter, a glassine bag, a burnt spoon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad. Dad. Dad. Finally, Paul realizes it's pointless and gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail Getty paces in the front lobby of Getty's headquarte

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: This poor woman, what she has endured! Gail is impeccably dressed and attended by her Italian attorney, the high-strung, diminutive GIOVANNI IACOVONI.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The decadence of the father, a depraved drug addict, living ina palace in Marrakech filled with hippie parasites. How she suffers with worry for her son!

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Giovanni, enough. This isn't Italy. We're not going before the Pope for an annulment.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: I know this, signora. I do this simply to get my blood flowing.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's all business to them. A TEAM OF SUITS file past en route to the conference room

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder how many people have ever managed to walk out of that conference room in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: Signora. Do not underestimate the power of a mother's love.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Right now I'd rather have a billionaire's money.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ms Getty, they're ready for you now.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long conference table, lined on either side with ATTORN At one end sits Gail Getty, with Iacovoni by her side.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Of course, we expect Ms. Getty will be seeking a generous financial settlement, as is typical in high- profile divorce cases. At the other end sits J Paul Getty, silent and aloof. Bes him, his lead attorney, OSWALD HINGE.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: As pertains to custody, there is the matter of Ms. Getty's fitness as a mother.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: The father is a drug addict who cannot tie his own shoes. You would leave the boy alone in Morocco with a rich degenerate?

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: The court will take a close interest in her psychological profile. We are asking the judge to order a complete evaluation by a panel of psychiatrists.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: Ms Harris suffers from a common affliction among the intelligent women, which is to fall in love with lo imbrogliare, losers, bums. Aside from this, she is in perfect mental health, you know this as well as I do. You are simply stalling, using the boy as a bargaining chip.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: We have all the time in the world.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: (vising) We will see you before the judge.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A deal. All eyes turn toward Gail.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: Did you say something?  22.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: The offer I'm about to make expires at the end of business today.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: Gail, please --

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: What is your offer, Ms. Harris?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Nothing. You pay nothing. No settlement, no alimony, no community property, no child support, nothing. Getty breaks in:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: In exchange, I want my son on a plane back home tonight. And full custody.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: What's your game?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't want your money.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Everybody wants my money.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You want your money. I want Paul. We can both have what we want.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I sense I'm being taken, I just don't know how.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty, why don't we take this under advisement. Gail removes her jewelry -- her engagement ring, earrings and sets them on the table before her.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I've watched you for years. You can't help yourself. Stiffing the bellboy. Re-using your dental floss. Searching other people's seat cushions for loose change -- Getty darkens. Gail changes tack, flattering him:  23.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn't get where you are without a healthy regard for the value of a dollar. You know a bargain when you see one. You know how to seize the initiative when your opponent is at his weakest. What I'm offering is the greatest bargain you're ever going to get. But free never lasts. She rises, leaving the jewelry on the table. Iacovoni tri to interrupt, but she ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six o'clock. HOLD on Getty. Over the sound of a PLANE LANDING we CUT T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Paul emerges from the gate into Gail's arms. She holds him tightly, exhausted and relieved. For a moment, accepts her embrace, but then:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I wanted to stay.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Let's just go home, OK?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I was happy with Dad and Talitha. Why'd you have to ruin it? He pulls away from her. As they walk through the airport, Paul walks on ahead, pulling farther away from her. Gail begins to reach out for him, but stops herself, givi him his freedom, until he is nearly lost in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail has been up all night. We have come full circle now, and have returned to the night of Paul's disappearance. Gail stands in the door of Paul's room, gazing at his bed which has not been slept in. Her other two kids are aslee

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Call me if you hear from him. No questions asked. Just tell him to come home. Gail hangs up the phone. She closes Paul's address book. QUICK CUTS: with no other way to fill her time, she tries work at her drafting table. She can't focus.  24. She cleans the bathroom instead. She washes the sheets in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail lies passed out on the bathroom floor, still wearing her rubber gloves. The apartment is immaculate. The kitchen phone RINGS. She wakes, rises, goes to it.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Yes. Si? The low VOICE on the other end speaks English with an acc

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Signora. We have your son.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Oh, God, thank you. Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Signora, we are kidnappers and have him captive. A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of joke?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: There must be some mistake.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No mistake. He is not harmed. We will send proof in the coming days.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I am Cinquanta. Paul is safe, but it will require $17 million to release him. Go to the police if you like, it makes no difference.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't have any money.  25.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get it from your father-in-law. He has all the money in the world. DIAL TONE. In the distance, we hear a SIREN approaching.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. SUTTON PLACE, (SURREY, ENGLAND)
dialogues.text: The PHONE CLATTERS into the receiver again. The secretary runs across the grounds, past the lion, up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty sits at his desk, his phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: They're here, Mr Getty.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Getty walks down a long mirrored corridor. He buttons his jacket, straightens his tie, shoots his cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: A throne room, literally. The chamber is lined with enorm tapestries and gilt mirrors. One side of the room is empty, the other packed with a ra of Fleet Street news reporters. When Getty enters, they start baying like hounds for his attention:

dialogues.speaker: TELEGRAPH REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty! Mr Getty! How much is the ransom for your grandson?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'll bet it's a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail is in the kitchen with the phone receiver pressed to her ear, her eyes closed. Gail's attorney Giovanni Iacovo is there, along with several Roman Squadra Mobile OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ms. Getty. Mr. Getty is unavailable at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Tell him it's regarding his grandson's kidnapping in Rome. I'1l wait. Gail looks out the window: in the street, dozens of REPOR and PAPARAZZI are teeming. At the sight of her face in th window they turn their cameras on her, flashes firing.  26.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Signora! The television! Gail stretches the phone cord into the living room to see her two other kids watching Getty's press conference on T

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (stunned) Never mind. I've found him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Standing before the reporters, Getty seems vague, distrac

dialogues.speaker: DAILY MAIL REPORTER
dialogues.text: Daily Mail here, Mr. Getty. We have reports that a note has arrived written in the boy's handwriting, demanding 17 million US dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: (whistles) $17 million? That's a lot of money for such a young boy.

dialogues.speaker: BBC REPORTER
dialogues.text: What steps will you be taking to secure your grandson's safety?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: None. The reporters are momentarily stunned silent.

dialogues.speaker: BBC REPORTER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we didn't get that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I have fourteen grandchildren. If I pay the ransom I will have fourteen kidnapped grandchildren. A MURMUR from the reporters as they process this statemen

dialogues.speaker: DAILY MAIL REPORTER
dialogues.text: You're a famously ruthless negotiator, Mr. Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: It's just that there's so little in life worth paying full price for.

dialogues.speaker: DAILY MAIL REPORTER
dialogues.text: How much would you pay for your grandson, if not 17 million?  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail watches Getty on TV. His eyes are devoid of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Good day, gentlemen. Getty turns and walks away. The press conference is over.

dialogues.speaker: TELEGRAPH REPORTER
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mr. Getty! What will you do to save your grandson's life? ON THE TV SCREEN: the door closes and Getty is gone.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ms. Getty? Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you like me to give Mr. Getty a message?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty returns to his office, followed by his secretary. S gives him Gail's message on a slip of paper; he folds it once, then throws it away. Getty stands there for a moment, pensive. The ticker-tape coils up snakelike on the floor at his feet, ignored. What will you do to save your grandson's life? Getty turns: his secretary is still standing there, gazin at him with those tremulous, pleading eyes. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Get me Fletcher Chace.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUDI DESERT
dialogues.text: undulates beneath us as we SOAR above it, from the POV of Peregrine falcon. We come over a rise and descend INTO --  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and onto the arm of a SHEIKH. The sheikh wears a Patek Phillipe and sunglasses, as do the others lounging on pil One man stands out from the rest: an American in a wrinkl khaki suit. God knows how he got here, but FLETCHER CHACE grins like a man who holds all the cards or is bluffing f all he's worth.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I feel for your situation, Your Royal Highness. Truly I do.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-RASHID
dialogues.text: Our agreement with Getty has brought us nothing but problems. The younger generation has become weak and lazy. Our children care about nothing but Lamborghinis and discotheques.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Perhaps then you would do well to accept our competitor's offer.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-RASHID
dialogues.text: How so, Mr Chace?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Maybe Standard Oil will find ways to siphon all that money away with their accounting tricks, and bring your wayward children closer to God. Fletcher Chace grins. The princes don't.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kidding aside, your highness. My employer has made you rich.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-RASHID
dialogues.text: Not as rich as him.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: If you renew your land-use agreement with Getty, he'll make you twice as rich. Can Standard Oil say that? (a beat) In America we have a saying: better to deal with the devil you know than the devil you don't. Another prince speaks, in Arabic:  29.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-WALID
dialogues.text: (to Al-Rashid) You know where Getty hired this one from? He belongs to the den of CIA spies that brought down Mossadegh --

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Belonged, Your Royal Highness. Past tense, please. (in English) I don't have the stomach for politics anymore. People tend to get hurt, and it's usually all the wrong people. Business is better. Nobody dies, they just go broke.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-RASHID
dialogues.text: For some people going broke is worse.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: That's why I work for Getty now. I've noticed people have a way of getting rich just standing next to him. People like you.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-WALID
dialogues.text: We don't need the Americans anymore. Our cartel, OPEC, will control inventory now. OPEC will set the oil price.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Nothing would make Mr. Getty happier than to see the price of oil higher. In fact, he'd be happy to help. Off on the horizon, a DUST DEVIL approaches, spiraling in the sky like a tornado.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE AL-RASHID
dialogues.text: Subhan Allah. Look. The sheikhs marvel at it, and then it is upon us:

dialogues.speaker: A DUNE BUGGY
dialogues.text: comes over the berm, fishtailing to a stop in the sand as the camels hiss and spit. A spattered OIL LANDMAN steps out of the dune buggy. He staggers through the sand and walks up to Fletcher Chace.

dialogues.speaker: OIL LANDMAN
dialogues.text: The old man wants you. Now.  30.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE, (SURREY, ENGLAND)
dialogues.text: Gail Getty sits in a chair in the mansion's waiting area. She's clad in Chanel from head-to-toe like a suit of armo along with a look of steely determination.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Mr. Getty is traveling at the moment and is unavailable. Gail eyes the dark-suited security guard in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Do you know why I'm here, Bullimore?

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am, I do.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have me thrown out, would you, Bullimore?

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: I would never turn you away from my home, ma'am. Or little Paul. But... this is not my home. An offscreen bell CHIMES. Bullimore excuses himself and lets aman in. It's Fletcher Chace. Bullimore takes his coat and umbrella and shows him to an adjacent waiting ar Chace leafs through a magazine. From his vantage, we can just spy a pair of STOCKING-CLAD LEGS around the corner. Chace rises, drifts into the front parlor, and pretends t examine a Vermeer still-life.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: How much would you say that painting's worth?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Hell if I know. Awfully small.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's a Vermeer. If I took it off the wall, do you think anyone would notice?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: A silent alarm would go off. The dogs would get to you before you made it to the fence. With a face as pretty as that... I wouldn't.  31.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You seem very knowledgeable.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: About paintings, no. About other things, some. Chace sits down opposite Gail.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's a tough old goat to get an audience with.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Chace. If you'll come with me.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Apparently not. Chace smiles sheepishly, rises, and leaves with Bullimore

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I need to stop off at the kitchen first, if that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chace uses a butcher's knife to cut a strip of raw meat f a porterhouse steak. He cuts the strip into cubes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: A GERMAN SHEPHERD patrols the grounds. Chace crouches; th dog runs to him. Chace feeds him the steak.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: That's it, Skip. Attaboy. What's this? He checks the dog's name tag: it reads "ANUBIS."

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: the nametag) Sorry about that, fella. Some things we don't get to choose. Chace takes in the scene by the pool: Getty sits on a cha lounge beside a young STARLET in a bathing suit. Getty la and jokes with her; she seems genuinely charmed.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This world was forged by two kinds of men, Mr Chace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty strolls with Chace around the pool.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men of enterprise, like myself. And men of action, like you. What you and I share is what most men lack: a willingness to embrace enormous risk. I risk my money. You risk your life.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I prefer to risk the other guy's life, actually.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I like to risk the other guy's money, too. My point is we represent a very small minority of mankind. The herd feeds off what we accomplish. These people who took my grandson -- what do you think I should have done?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: You did the right thing. They won't hurt the boy, he's a winning lottery ticket. Pay them too quickly and they may be afraid they asked for too little. They might come back for another bite.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: If only everyone was as clear-headed as you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Gail is still cooling her heels in Getty's front hall. Sh rises and approaches Bullimore.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I need to phone my attorney to find out if there's been any contact from the kidnappers.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: Of course, Ma'am. This way. Bullimore leads Gail around the corner of the entry hall. He shows her to a RED PUBLIC TELEPHONE BOOTH of the kind found on the streets of London.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty had it installed specially for his guests' convenience, in case they wanted to make telephone calls.  33.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Rome is long distance.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: I am able to provide change. Bullimore produces a small change dispenser. Gail stares him. She reaches into her purse and gives him a ten-pound note. Bullimore parses out the coins.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll leave you in private.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You don't have children, do you, Chace. Chace shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I guess it didn't seem right, doing what I do for a living. Maybe I never found the right situation. I liked my freedom.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I know just what you mean. There's something my father always used to say: "The man who has children gives hostages to fortune."

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Your father was a wise man.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: He told me I'd never be worth a damn. So I made him look like a pauper.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Well. You certainly did that. An awkward silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I love my grandson, Chace.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I love all my grandchildren, of course. But Paul is special. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know what I would do if anything happened to that boy. I want you to go to Rome and bring him back, as quickly and inexpensively as possible.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm going to need some kind of resources to work with if you want him back alive.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Of course. But I don't want you just giving my money away, see. Find the boy, Chace. And find out who took him. Chace walks away, a look of uncertainty on his face.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chace. There's one more thing. (a beat) The boy's mother.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Gail Getty sits in the phone booth, stuffing 50p coins in the coin slot.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm running out of change, Giovanni... Giovanni? The phone goes dead. She's out of change. She hangs up th receiver and slouches into the phone booth, dejected.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Gail looks up. Fletcher Chace is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Fletcher Chace. I'm going to help you find your son.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Gail walks back into the entry hall, annoyed. Chace follo

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're quite good at what you do, Mr. Chace. My former father- in-law only buys the best. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I don't need a retired policeman, or a former secret agent, or a plastic toy soldier to solve the mystery of what happened to my son, because there is no mystery. I don't needa man of danger to catch the criminals. I need one thing only, and that is seventeen million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Paying the ransom doesn't guarantee you get your son back.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Not paying the ransom nearly guarantees I don't.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'd say your son's chances are better than that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Why don't you explain the odds to me. Is it a coin toss? Heads he lives, tails he dies? I can see how that's a gamble worth taking when there's real money at stake --

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Let me rephrase that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: A billion dollars earns seventeen million dollars a month sitting in a bank vault. He could buy a Matisse every day and never spend it all.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I don't think this is about money for Mr. Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't realize this was your first day on the job.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I've had to bargain with a lot of rich people. Sheikhs, sultans, emirs. The one thing I've realized is that money is never just money. It always stands for something. Usually it stands for the one thing they've never had. Until you know what that thing is you're just beating your head against the bricks. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a beat) Look, I don't blame you. You came here for seventeen million dollars and instead you got me. But I'm the one who has the old man's ear, and I'm offering to help you.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving until I speak to him face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Mr. Getty has already departed the estate. Gail turns. Through the window, we see Getty's limousine driving through the front gates, and away.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He is traveling on business, and it is uncertain when he will return. Gail stares out the window, her back to us, visibly tremb Bullimore brings Chace's coat and hat.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll want to be getting back to Rome on the next flight out. I'm headed there myself. I can offer you a ride to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: BULLIMORE
dialogues.text: I'll dial a taxicab straight away. Gail is silent. Finally she turns. Her voice is icy:

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You're both much too kind.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUNK OPENS
dialogues.text: revealing a cloudless blue sky. Two men step into frame. One is stout, bearded, chubby-cheeked. He smokes a cigar with an air of authority. This is CHIPMUNK. The other is rough but handsome, with the style that even the poorest of Italians somehow manage. This is CINQUANTA They gaze at us as you would at a rug that needs moving.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Uno, due --  37. They reach in and hoist us out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men carry Paul's body across the sun-bleached, ro landscape out of a Sergio Leone movie. Paul's arms and le have been tied off; his head is inside a burlap sack. They set the boy down beneath a wizened tree. Cinquanta pulls down his ski mask, then removes the burlap sack fro Paul's head. The boy, fearful, avoids looking at them. A severely bow-legged man emerges from the house. This is PICCOLINO, and he is their leader. Piccolino bends down, examines the boy as you would a goat, then smiles. The men embrace in celebration. Laughing, back-slapping. pretty young woman comes out with a tin plate of beans an pasta. Cinquanta orders her to give it to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thirsty. Cinquanta yells orders at his wife again.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: A few days. That's all. Your family will give us our money, and you'll go home. Some days, no school, it's fun. A holiday. The boy eats. The food tastes terrible.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: Our food's not good enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm just not used to it.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. He eats only in the best places, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Not usually, though.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: You'll tell us. I want to know all the things the rich eat. I am Cinquanta, this is Piccolino, and this is Tamia, the Chipmunk. Not our real names, eh?  38.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I figured.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: We'll make friends. I'1l tell you things about me, and you tell me things about you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't want to know anything about you.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Smart boy. We talk about you then.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you want to know about me?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Tell me about your grandfather. Tell me about your mother. Tell me about the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fletcher Chace sits in an aisle seat, studying his files Gail and Little Paul. The STEWARDESS cracks open a tiny airplane bottle of Campari for him and pours it into a gl

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Mille grazie, signorina. We PULL BACK along the aisle -- to where Gail sits at a w seat, eyeing Fletcher Chace warily from behind dark glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate opens, and a flood of REPORTERS and PAPARAZZI ar waiting for us. FLASHBULBS click and whirr like locusts.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: Signora, Signora! Is your son still alive? Signora!

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Out of the way, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: When will you pay the ransom for your son's life?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't have the money. The reporters laugh.  39.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: You divorced the son of the richest man in the world, Signora!

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't have to answer questions.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: No. I want to say something. Gail's voice is tense with emotion, but she remains poise

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My son Paul must be very frightened right now. I know I'm frightened for him. So to the people who took him: I don't care why you did this, but as a mother I ask you to think of your own children, or of the child you once were, and set my boy free. A brief silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: (to Chace) Scusi. Why does the lady not cry?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: Your son is disappeared. A mother should cry for her son.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You want me to cry, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: All right. Let the lady through. The crowd parts before us to reveal the smartly-dressed Investigating Magistrate ANTONIO DEL ROVERE flanked by tw uniformed officers of the Italian POLICIA DI STATO. The flashbulbs pop and whirr, recording the moment:

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Ms. Getty. I am Antonio Del Rovere of the Policia di Stato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del Rovere leads Gail and Chace from a police sedan in th parking garage into the front lobby of a castle that has been transformed into a police Questura.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Your son is a very lucky boy, Signora.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Nothing about this feels lucky to me.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Of course, it's a terrible thing. But if he had to be taken, this is the best place it could happen. No police department in the world has solved more kidnappings.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: How did you earn that distinction? Rovere leads them up the marble staircase.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: A few years ago we had an outbreak of kidnapping. Wealthy people, ordinary Italians, everyone. This was how the communist Rosso Brigate financed their terrorist activities. Everyone paid the ransom, no matter what we told them to do.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What about the families that refused to pay?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Even the poorest family will give up everything to have their children back. So I devised a solution. We froze the bank accounts of the all the families so they couldn't pay.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Is that legal?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: If the police do it, it must be legal. It took some time but they realized the money wouldn't come. Now it seems they've decided to take foreigners instead.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Freezing J Paul Getty's money is not going to be an option in this case.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I've forgotten which party you said you were working for.  41.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I represent Mr. Getty's interests. I'm his head of security.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: And what are Mr. Getty's interests?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Business, sex, and the collecting of art. In that order. Del Rovere laughs, but Gail's not joking.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you're about to inform us you have some information about my son. Has anyone stepped forward to claim responsibility for his kidnapping?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Tutti, Signora. Everybody. He opens a door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to a darkened room filled with glowing LIGHT TABLES wh INSPECTORS examine ransom letters, dusting for fingerprin

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: These letters are addressed to me. You've been opening my mail -- ?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: It may be your mail, but it's our evidence. All these letters are from people claiming to have kidnapped your son. From all over the world. Germany, California, faster than we can investigate.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: $17 million brings out a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You're telling me you have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: No, Signora, we have too much. Too many kidnappers, too many reporters. A victim worth too much money.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Want some free advice? Put it in the papers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When the kidnappers find out every lowlife in Rome is trying to poach their ransom they'll have to come out into the open to claim it.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: It's the communists, the Rosso Brigate. To kidnap the child of the richest capitalist in the world -- this would be a dream for them. They will take you too, Signora, if they can. So I am placing you under police protection.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't need anyone's protection. I'm not a real Getty. I never was. I'm an ordinary person.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: You're not a person anymore. You're a symbol. My officers will escort you home. Buona sera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail and Chace ride in back as the police car blazes thro the streets. Plastered along the walls are blowups of the cover of La Stampa with Paul Getty's photograph on it. A MOTORBIKE pulls up alongside Gail's window. The rider reaches into his bag and we see the glint of black metal

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Jesus, shake them off. Swerve! And a FLASHBULB FIRES. The Paparazzo shoves his camera ba into his bag and speeds away. Gail never flinched.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Didn't you see that?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE DRIVER
dialogues.text: It's a free country. Gail looks over at the flustered Chace.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's kind of you to make a fuss, Mr. Chace, but you really needn't bother.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, two SURVEILLANCE OFFICERS of the Policia Stato are setting up a large reel-to-reel tape recorder o the table and connecting it to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Is there anywhere you can put that so that we have a place to eat?

dialogues.speaker: SURVEILLANCE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Your child is kidnapped, Signora. How can you think about eating? This stings.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Do what you have to do. In the living room, Chace is examining her belongings: th apartment is simple but stylish as Gail herself. Gail's daughter Ariadne walks in in her pajamas, rubbing sleep from her eyes. Chace is awkward.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Hi there.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Back to bed, darling.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: All these strange men in her house. Gail tucks her daughter back into bed. Meanwhile, Chace enters Little Paul's room. When Gail re-enters, she finds Chace rifling through books on the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did Paul do any drugs? Marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He was a teenage boy. He had teenage boy problems. He made teenage boy mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to find it before those guys in the kitchen do.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: They've already searched this room.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: He'd gotten in trouble at school, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: A boy needs a father, and his was strung out in Marrakech with Mick Jagger. It was all I could do to get him to come home at night. He opens a copy of "Watership Down" and a tiny bag of has falls out. Gail eyes Gail looks He pockets it. He finds Paul's address book.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Can I take this? him warily.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Do you carry a gun, Mr. Chace? (off his look) You said you used to be a spy.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: That's not how I put it on my tax return, but yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Spies carry guns.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I never bothered. Ruins the line of your suit. Guns are for people who don't have money. (a beat) All that spooky paperback stuff -- chasing around blowing poisoned darts at the KGB in the Arab Quarter -- that's not what I did for a living.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What did you do, then?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I made deals. I bought people. I whispered in Generals' ears. at him, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Take it. Chace pockets the address book, rises, and returns to the living room. The mustached Surveillance Officer from the kitchen -- his name is CORVO -- approaches Gail.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: One final question, Signora. About your testimony earlier. Why did you think the kidnapping was a joke? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CORVO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off her look) You said that when you first received the phone call from Cinquanta you thought it was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: That's what passed through my mind.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: It's a strange reaction, is it not? Someone tells the mother her son is kidnapped and she thinks it's funny?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I didn't think it was funny at all. It seemed unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: You didn't believe the man on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's a figure of speech. The whole situation was unbelievable. It still is.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: Tragic, yes. But not unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: It's not tragic yet. Maybe you ought to work on keeping it that way.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: A figure of speech, as you say. Please let us know, Signora, if you plan to leave Italy for any reason. Corvo bows slightly and heads for the door with his partn

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Why do you think he said that?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to get rid of them?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: When the time comes I'll do it myself. Good evening, Mr. Chace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chace exits the building by a side entrance, past the hal dozen paparazzi camped outside.  46. He casts a final glance up at Gail's glowing window, then disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We DESCEND into a cave deep in the Calabrian mountains. A army cot has been set up in here, with wooden boxes for t and chairs. Years of crude graffiti on the walls. Deep inside the cave Cinquanta finds an unlit oil lamp. H takes out a match and lights it -- -- REVEALING a bunk bed set up in here, and Paul is chain to it. Cinquanta reaches into his bag. He brings out a ca of beans and a composition notebook.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Write another letter to your mother. Tell her if she doesn't pay, we'll mail her your finger. Cinquanta sets down a BALLPOINT PEN. The boy takes it. Cinquanta eyes him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why doesn't your family love you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think they love me. I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? Are you a bad boy?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Don't lie. What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I set a fire at my school and they kicked me out. Cinquanta considers this. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Boys play with fire. I did. If my son was kidnapped, bad, good, I would pay any money to get him back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They're going to pay. They just need to get used to the idea of it.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I would get the money. I would borrow it. Steal. OK, I steal anyway, but I would steal more.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You have a kid? (realizes) I shouldn't have asked that.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Once. For a few weeks, that's all. My wife put him to sleep in the crib. In the morning the baby was cold. No life. The doctor gave no reason. No answer. Nothing. Cinquanta suddenly seems angry.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Americans! I don't understand you. For us, family is everything. We are obbligo. I was born into my family, and that decides my whole life. My whole life.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm obbligo too. As much as you. Cinquanta looks at Paul. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: When we get the money, we'll run away from them. To America, eh? Cinquanta gazes out of the cave at a patch of blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A Corvette. That's a nice car. Just drive away. He snaps out of it. He hits the boy on the back of the he

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cazzo! What are you doing? Write. Convince her to pay us our money or Mother of God I'll kill you myself. Cinquanta takes the notebook and exits, leaving the pen a matches. Paul slips them into the sleeve of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reel-to-reel tape recorder sits in the center of the table. The kids eat their cereal beside it in their pajam Gail throws open the curtains to let the light in --  48. -- spray-painted in dripping red on the wall outside the window is a FIVE-POINTED STAR. It seems the remnant of so satanic ritual. Painted above it, the words ROSSO BRIGATE She pulls the curtain shut. Her kids continue eating, obl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle and Julian, Gail's friends, wait for her at the foot of the gangplank as she boards their 47-footer.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Gail, I'm so sorry. Isabelle embraces Gail. For a moment Gail allows herself melt into her friend's arms.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Gail's hosts serve a light lunch on deck. Gail can't eat.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're torn up for you. What you must be going through.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: And the papers can't help any.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I'm going through. I sleep in a warm bed every night. God only knows where Paul's sleeping. I mean, look at me, I'm on a yacht.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: That's the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (summoning her nerve) I don't know how else to say this. You're my friends, so I thought I could turn to you. I need money. For the ransom.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: We don't have that kind of money. We're not Gettys.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We could get some friends together. Here aboard your boat. The money would be paid back in full, I can't say when but --  49.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I mean, when you think how fortunate that boy has been. The money he'll inherit one day.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: All of us are fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Not like that. He's set for life.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He has to live that long first. The money shouldn't matter. He's just a boy, an ordinary boy.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Of course it matters, Gail. You'd be asking us, asking our friends, to give a fortune to a boy who's worth more money than they'll ever have.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: If I could think of another way I wouldn't be asking.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: And let's be honest, Paul was no angel.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You're saying he deserved this?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Of course not, but it wasn't entirely a surprise, either. Privileged kids get into trouble. If it's not drugs --

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Everything comes too easy.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I forgot how you built yourselves up from nothing. A silence. A crewman comes to take away their salad plate

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (a forced smile) You'll see. In a few weeks we'll all be sailing to Portofino again, like none of this ever happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fletcher Chace walks with a newspaper folded beneath his arm. He passes a streetlight with an "X" marked in chalk.  50. Parked twenty paces from the streetlight is a white plumb van. Chace knocks on the rear door twice, and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bland-looking young fellow frisks Chace.

dialogues.speaker: BLAND FELLOW
dialogues.text: Siediti perfavore. Chace obeys. The van lurches into motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bland fellow leads Chace out of the garage into a spa decorated home. Chace is led to a chair in the dining roo A red ROSSO BRIGATE flag is draped over one wall.

dialogues.speaker: BLAND FELLOW
dialogues.text: Perfavore. Chace obeys. A lamp is switched on, shining in his eyes. FRANCESCI, a mustached young man in a corduroy sportcoat, seated beside the lamp. A gun is on the table beside him. There are others in the room. Chace squints at them.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: You don't look like communists.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: What do communists look like?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Workers. Wasn't that the original idea?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: You look like accountants.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: Let's talk about the money.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: First you prove to me that you have the boy and he's in good health. Then we negotiate the terms. But first the proof.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: First the money. Then the boy.  51.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: It doesn't work that way. You know that. You're supposed to be pros.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: No conditions.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I don't think you have the kid. An intense young woman, MARGHERITA, speaks:

dialogues.speaker: MARGHERITA
dialogues.text: Why are we negotiating with him? We should try him and put him to death.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: MARGHERITA
dialogues.text: For crimes against the proletariat.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Now I know you don't have the kid. If you kill me, Getty's just going to send someone else like me. Unless he doesn't, in which case where does that leave you? Think, comrade.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: We had an agreement.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Who had an agreement?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: We did. With Paul. Chace's smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: Paul used to talk about having himself kidnapped. With his friends, out on the street. A game, no one gets hurt. A way to make a little money from his grandfather, two million dollars perhaps. That's what we do. Chace rubs his eyes, suddenly weary.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Did Paul know who you were?  52.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: We made friends with him. We told him we could help. But then he disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: MARGHERITA
dialogues.text: We believe he found someone else.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: And now you want -- what? A finder's fee? A consolation prize?

dialogues.speaker: MARGHERITA
dialogues.text: The people are owed.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
