dialogues.text: вЂњThe people," or just the people in this room? And here I thought you all were supposed to be above money.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: No one is above money. The problem is that it's in the wrong hands. We intend to get what is our due.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: (vising) I'll save you a place in line.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: I'm curious. What would Getty pay for you?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Don't bother. He wouldn't pay a dime for me. Neither would anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCI
dialogues.text: I've never met anyone who couldn't think of someone who would pay for his life.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: There's a first time for everything. Now are you going to drive me back, or am I going to walk out the front door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stretch of barren highway out by an industrial plant. T white van slows, its door opens, and Chace is shoved out. The van speeds away. Chace picks himself up off the aspha dusts himself off, and looks around. He is utterly lost.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chace stands in Gail's doorway. She seems taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You've got to remember who the Gettys are. Every time someone stays in the bathroom too long people start making jokes about being held for ransom. He might have cracked a joke once or twice among friends --

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: There's that word again.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What word?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: A joke. When it first happened you said you thought it was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Now you sound like that policeman.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Did Paul ever talk to you about having himself kidnapped?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Whose side are you on, Mr Chace?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm on my own side, always. And if there's a joke I like to make sure I'm in on it.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: New developments have come to light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del Rovere and Corvo have come to Chace's hotel. A news report about the OPEC summit plays on TV behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: Gail Getty is two months behind on the rent on her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: The lady needed money.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: So do I.  54.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: So do we all. But Gail Getty gave up a chance to make a fortune in her divorce. Did you know?

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: We calculated the money Ms Getty could have expected in her settlement. The number was 15 to 18 million dollars. Quite a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm impressed you had any time at all to look for the kid.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: Then there is the matter of Gail's lover. Chace blinks. Corvo takes out a picture of a handsome Sicilian. It's a police booking photo.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Luigi Della Ratta. A casino croupier, very much a ladies' man, with reputed criminal connections. Chace stares at the photo.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: It should have been obvious. A pretty lady like this, expensive tastes, so insistent to get Getty to pay the ransom --

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: But never does she cry for her child. How can a mother not cry? Chace pushes the photo away.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Nice work, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: And you? Have you learned anything?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: You look like you've tasted something you don't like. If you don't like your drink, just get another.  55.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: This is going to kill the old man. It has to stay out of the papers.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Nothing leaves this table. It's for the best, eh? There was never any danger. You have only to wait for the boy to return. Del Rovere rises, and Corvo with him. He nods at a DARK- HAIRED BEAUTY at the other end of the bar and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A single man alone in Rome on the Getty expense account. I envy you. The two men grin as they leave Chace at the bar. Chace glances up at the TV. On a Bolletino Straordinario, the SHAH OF IRAN is making a speech:

dialogues.speaker: SHAH OF IRAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course the price of oil must rise. You increased the price of wheat you sell us by 3008, it's only fair that, from now on, you should pay more for oil. Let's say ten times more. CUT TO A WIDE: all that remains of Fletcher Chace is the he's left on the bar. He's already gone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE, (SURREY, ENGLAND)
dialogues.text: Rain. The great gates open for Fletcher Chace.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: J Paul Getty and Chace walk side-by-side.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I wish I could say I'm surprised. Getty approaches a statue by the reflecting pool. He puts his hand upon it, as if for support. He seems badly shake

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Mr Getty?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: When I wrote my book, "How to Be Rich," the publisher called me and said they wanted to change the title. They wanted to call it "How To Get Rich." They thought it would sell more copies. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I told them getting rich is easy. Any fool can get rich, and a remarkable number of fools do.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I've noticed that.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: But being rich -- that's hard. See, the ordinary working man has to go to work to feed his family. Maybe he hates his job, hates his boss, but the drive for survival gives him a purpose in life. When a man gets rich, he's faced with the problem of freedom. An abyss opens up before him. I've seen it ruin men, and marriages, and most of all it ruins the children.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: He's a kid. Kids do stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I thought I could trust my own blood.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: He's probably lying on a beach somewhere. When he gets bored or runs out of money he'll come home. And he'll have learned his lesson.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I wanted to give him everything, give him all my knowledge, all I've built, and he just wanted to pick my pocket. Like his father, like his uncle, like the parasites that have swarmed around me my entire life. Getty walks on, through his sculpture garden.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's why I like things, see. They are what they appear to be, and they never change. They never disappoint. There's a purity to beautiful things that I've never been able to find in another human being.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Neither have I. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off his look) You were right not to pay the ransom. You were right to follow your gut. Getty turns away from Chace, suddenly distant.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You performed well. This will be reflected in your year-end bonus.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Go back to Rome. Wait there for Paul to return. But your investigation is closed. The search is over. BLACK OUT.

dialogues.speaker: A PATCH OF BLUE SKY
dialogues.text: framed by the mouth of the cave. We HEAR the kidnappers arguing, their voices echoing off the cave walls. In the darkness Paul listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chipmunk, toting a shotgun, leads Little Paul on a windin trail through the mountains. The weather is turning cold; the boy is wrapped in a blanket. They approach a creek be

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: Do you have to go? Here's your chance. I'm not taking you out again. Paul shakes his head. Chipmunk scratches at his mask.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't eat, that's why. Our food isn't good enough for you. Wait here. Chipmunk climbs down into the ravine, out of sight of the boy. He peels back his ski mask for a moment, then unzips and begins to urinate. He zips up and climbs back up the ravine. Paul stares at him for a moment, then quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you looking at -- ?  58. Chipmunk reaches for his mask, and realizes he never pull it back down.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pezzo di merda! You saw my face!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn't see anything!

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: Figlia di puttana! Culo! He pulls the ski mask down, then realizes it's pointless. He pulls it off and starts kicking it across the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You saw my face! Don't lie!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I won't tell anyone what you look like, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: You little shit. You've ruined everything. Chipmunk raises his shotgun at Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Run. Run away. Fretta!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE PAUL
dialogues.text: No. You're gonna shoot me in the back and tell them I tried to escape. Paul shakes his head, closing his eyes and refusing to tu his back. Chipmunk gives up. He kicks the ski mask again.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: Manache! Have it your way. Worse for you. You'll wish you ran! Chipmunk grabs Paul and drags him back down the hill towa the squat stucco house in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is tethered to a rock by a rope around his neck as g graze around him. He watches the little house: inside, Piccolo, Cinquanta and Chipmunk are arguing. Paul leans over and pulls at the tether. Desperate, he be to chew on it. The men's voices grow ever louder.  59. Then they fall silent. The front door of the house opens and three men walk out -- Cinquanta and Chipmunk in the l with the bow-legged Piccolino falling behind.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: I told you. Chipmunk is carrying his shotgun. He chambers a shell. Paul begins to whimper desperately.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Please. Don't. The money. You can still get the money. Chipmunk closes the shotgun and raises it at Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPMUNK
dialogues.text: You had to ruin it for everyone. Now Piccolino raises his gun as well. He FIRES and we

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE RINGS
dialogues.text: and a groggy Fletcher Chace fumbles in the dark. A copy o Getty's book "How To Be Rich" is open on the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Who's. Yes. Si?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mister Chace. We are requesting you and Ms. Getty to report to the Questura.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To identify the body.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: The body?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul's body. Paul Getty. Chace is suddenly alert.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Paul's. (blinks) OK, yes. Va bene. We're coming.  60. Chace hangs up. He sits up and starts pacing the room. Th raven-haired beauty from the bar is in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: SICILIAN BEAUTY
dialogues.text: PerchГ©, Fletcher? Chace starts putting on his clothes in a hurry. He starts to pick up the phone, then puts it down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail opens the door wearing her robe.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Chace -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Gail.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh God. She covers her face with her hands. Chace looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Squadra Mobile car speeds through the night. Chace st furtive glances at Gail.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Mistakes were made, obviously, somehow. My investigation and the police's led us to the conclusion that there was no physical danger --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr Chace. I'm on my way to identify my son's body. I don't feel like talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morgue dates to the 19th century; it's dank as a cata The body is laid out on a marble slab, covered by a sheet

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: The corpse has been in sea water for some hours when it washed ashore. The appearance may be a shock. We gaze up at their faces as they gather round the table. The elderly CORONER pulls back the sheet.  61.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: God damn! Chace reels. Gail almost faints. She shakes her head "no. REVERSE ANGLE: the bloated, waterlogged body on the table isn't Paul. It's Chipmunk. He has an ugly exit wound in his chest from where he was shot in the back by Piccolino

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's not him. It's not Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: The guy has five o'clock shadow, for Christ's sake. He was headed for a midlife crisis when they shot him.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: A sailor by the harbor saw a body being thrown from a white Fiat 600, like the car the kidnappers drove.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: This country's infested with Fiat 600s. First you said it was a hoax, then you tell us they murdered him. Why don't you make up your mind?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: No one stopped you doing your own job, Mr Chace. You did that yourself. Chace is momentarily speechless.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Scusi. Everyone turns. The ancient coroner is picking at the bod on the slab with a pair of tweezers. He plucks something from Chipmunk's beard, holds it up to the light: RED FIBE

dialogues.speaker: CORONER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Un filato de tessuto rosso.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: The carpet the body was transported in. The coroner shakes his head, mimes scratching at his bear

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Una maschera.  62.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: A ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Chipmunk. There's more than one to choose from, going all the way back to his childhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police clerks search through boxes of criminal photo files. Photos of Chipmunk are pinned to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: Ettore "Il Tamia" Pazzano, age 33 years. Purse snatching, public indecency, vandalism, desecration of a holy place, corruption of the youth. PHOTOS of Cinquanta and Piccolino are pinned up on the bo

dialogues.speaker: CORVO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Known associates: Alberto Laganadi, Dino Bova, Dante Agnana, all from Fiumara, Calabria, population 1381.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: How fast can we get to Fiumara?

dialogues.speaker: A CONVOY OF SQUADRA MOBILE VEHICLES
dialogues.text: On the unpaved road through the Calabrian mountains: we g down at them from a police helicopter circling high overh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police cars stop on the mountain road and the uniform police climb out. Del Rovere instructs Chace:

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: I must ask you to stay here. For your own safety. Chace watches Rovere head off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: (to Gail) Stay here. Chace opens the door and climbs out. The officer at the wheel protests, but Chace ignores him. Then Gail climbs o as well, and the cop goes apoplectic.  63.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Arrest me. We can see the stone house from several hundred meters aw as the police create a wide perimeter encircling it. Near a SQUADRA OFFICER questions a GOATHERD. Gail listens in:

dialogues.speaker: GOATHERD
dialogues.text: ..-hanno mantenuto il ragazzo in una grotta nelle montagne... Gail starts walking up the mountain road, in the opposite direction from the police, and Chace follows. They reach the mouth of the cave, which is littered with cigarette b Gail enters. Chace casts a glance back: in the pasture fa below, the police cordon around the stone house draws tig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD on GAIL as she moves deeper into the dark, follow the last of daylight into its depths. Then she finds it:

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul. PAUL'S BED, empty. The chain and shackle lie beside it, a Paul's Fantastic Comics lies on the ground. An unfinished letter in his handwriting crumpled beside it.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "If you love me, Mother -- GUNSHOTS ring out, the echoes multiplying off the cave wa Gail and Chace hurry to the mouth of the cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is riddled with gunfire, the windows shattered. Piccolino slumps in the doorway with his shotgun in the d beside him. Del Rovere kicks the gun aside.

dialogues.speaker: PICCOLINO
dialogues.text: Molti poliziotti... So many police. Tanti...

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Where is the boy?

dialogues.speaker: PICCOLINO
dialogues.text: Lo abbiamo venduto. Piccolino coughs, drowning in his own blood. A sad smile.

dialogues.speaker: PICCOLINO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We sold him.  64.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Sold him to whom?

dialogues.speaker: SAVERIO MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: walks through a factory where women sew counterfeit Fendi handbags. Mammoliti examines the workmanship on one of th handbags, comparing it against the genuine article.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: This lining. It needs to be double- stiched to look like the real Fendi My buyer can tell the difference. Mammoliti is forty years old, blankly handsome, and dress in a tailored suit: he could easily be seen in the busine class lounge of any international airport in the world.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it again. Mammoliti hands the bag back to the woman. She nods, care not to make eye contact: she is frightened of him.

dialogues.speaker: FACTORY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Sicuramente, Signore. Perdonami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saverio Mammoliti sits in the backseat, his briefcase ope beside him, perusing a balance sheet. His bald-shaven driver/bodyguard, SGRO, pulls over behind a tractor-trail

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cargo door rolls open, revealing pallets of counterfe goods. Paul Getty is in back, guarded by two of Mammoliti men. Cinquanta is here as well.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: (re: Cinquanta) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: SGRO
dialogues.text: He comes with the boy. Mammoliti looks Cinquanta over; a 21st Century gangster looking back at a Stone Age one.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: Get him out of here. I don't want him around.  Cinquanta

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: It was part of our deal. I help with the kid. I look after him.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: Your services are no longer required.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: The mother and I. Gail Getty. We have a dialogue. I can help you get the money.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: We know how to get the money. It's not that hard if you have the stomach for it.

dialogues.speaker: SGRO
dialogues.text: You heard him. reluctantly rises. Paul watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does he do what you say?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Always. He's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: He's not eating. Look at him. We need him to eat meat, lots of meat. Build up his blood. Do you understand my meaning?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand your meaning.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: Va bene. You work for us now.

dialogues.speaker: SAUDI PRINCES
dialogues.text: emerge from the 1973 Extraordinary Summit of OPEC.

dialogues.speaker: SUMMIT, VIENNA, AUSTRIA
dialogues.text: The princes' white robes billow in the breeze; they wear triumphant smiles of men who have seized an historic mome

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GETTY'S LIMOUSINE pulls up in front of the Exchange. J Pa Getty emerges, resplendent in a Saville Row three-piece a accompanied by two lacquered YOUNGISH WOMEN in tight dres  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty takes his seat overlooking the exchange, flanked by his two concubines, like an Emperor at the Arena. The tra on the floor await the opening bell with dread and excite Getty's FLOOR TRADER hurries up the steps to take his ord Getty pats his stomach, like a man who can't eat any more

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: No trades for me, George. My long book's all topped up. Truth is, I woke up this morning about as long as I've been since I was a teenager. The ladies titter and smirk. One leans in, confidential:

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS
dialogues.text: He just likes to watch. Getty shoots her a reproving "bad girl" look. She puts ou her hand and he pinches it playfully.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Watch carefully, girls. In sixty seconds half the men in this room will be bankrupt. The seconds tick down. The floor traders brace themselves We PUSH IN on Getty as the OPENING BELL RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boarding gate door opens and Fletcher Chace emerges wearing a suit, sunglasses and a repentant look. Then he sees something that stops him cold:

dialogues.speaker: EMBARGO
dialogues.text: headlined on every London newspaper's evening edition: "O shuts off global oil supply."

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I got on the plane this morning oil was $4 per barrel.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Chace walks the halls alongside Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You should have bought it. No one will ever see that price again. Getty's secretary hurries up to him in her high heels. Sh hands him a slip of ticker tape.  67.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The New York open, Mr. Getty.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I think it's time to reassess our strategy --

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Shh. Getty reads the tape and gazes into the distance. Then he's

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: What are you doing, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Multiplication. done. The number seems to surprise even him.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A good day.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear that, Mr Getty. It'll make this much easier. (a beat) We need to pay the ransom.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You said it was a hoax.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Your grandson was kidnapped by members of the Calabrian N'dragheta, the oldest of all Italian Mafias. Two of the original kidnappers are dead and one is missing.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: That sounds like progress to me.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. They got nervous waiting for the ransom and sold the boy to an investor.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: You told me Paul and his mother cooked this up to soak me.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I was wrong. Paul may have talked about being kidnapped with his friends. He may have put it out there but I don't believe he's behind this.  68.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: How do I know you're not wrong now?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Look, these people aren't the old- world malavita anymore. They're businessmen. Their only code is profit and loss. They'll do things to Paul that can't be undone for any amount of money.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Paul got himself into this. The boy's going to have to live with the consequences of his actions.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Don't let him die just for being a child. We have to pay.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: It simply isn't possible right now. My financial position has changed.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I'm not all that bright but I can multiply as well as you. With oil up 7% this morning you made a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Precisely. I'm highly leveraged to the price of oil right now.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: In the middle of an oil embargo I'd say that's a good place to be.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: When the oil price is rising, it is. But what if the price of oil were suddenly to fall? What if the embargo is lifted? What then? I would be exposed. Do you know how Jesse Livermore died?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I don't know who he was.  69.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: He was the greatest speculator in stocks ever to work on Wall Street. He blew his brains out in a coat check room after he lost every penny he had. That's how fast a man's fortune can turn. Don't you see? I've never been more vulnerable financially than I am right now.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: No one has ever been richer than you are at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I don't have the money to spare.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: What would it take? How much would it take for you to feel secure?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: More. Chace is struck silent. Getty turns on him:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't need to hire an ex-CIA officer just to pay people off. I can do that myself. I hired you to do things other people can't, or won't. That means rescuing the boy.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I can't do it without money.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: There is no money. You'll have to get the boy on your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall-mounted phone RINGS. Gail answers it.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Signora.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Where is my son?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He is still in good health. I am with him, don't worry. In the BG, Chace turns the reel-to-reel tape recorder on.  70.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's because of you I worry. I want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid this I cannot do. I am not in charge anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chace appears at Gail's shoulder. Gail hands him the phon

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: This is Fletcher Chace. Mr. Getty has authorized me to negotiate on his behalf. We will cover all your expenses up to $200,000. Anything under this figure is not considered extortion under Italian law so you can walk away free and clear.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The boy is worth much more. They're not stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: The boy is worth nothing to anyone. We're just trying to settle this without causing any more embarrassment to the family.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My God --

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: He's a juvenile delinquent. His grandfather's disowned him. It's a tough break you took the wrong kid, but you're getting off easy.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: You arrogant bastard.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Your uncle Piccolino died in custody last night, by the way. You ought to take this deal before the same happens to you. Chace calmly hangs up the receiver. A hand reaches into frame, picks up the receiver, and HITS him with it.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughs) Whoa there -- ! But the next one connects. Gail hits him again, pushing h back over the stove. Dishes come out of the cupboard and rain down in shatters. Everything collapses to the kitchen floor. Chace grabs at Gail's wrists as they grapple atop broken plates. Somewhe Gail's children are crying. Then she's off him. Chace is lying on his back looking up at the ceiling, bleeding from a split lip. She disappears, taking her crying children with her. Chac is left lying on the kitchen floor. Gail re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need some ice or I'll bleed all over your floor. Gail reaches into the freezer, pulls out a tray of ice, a drops it onto the floor. Chace rubs ice cubes on his face

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I lied. I said I was authorized to pay them $200,000. You know how much I'm really authorized to pay? Nothing. If they accept I won't be able to deliver but I had to buy some time. You wanted to know what I used to do? This is what I used to do. What I still do, for Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You "make deals." You "buy people."

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: That's right. Whether it's a pit of grease in the desert or a human life it's all the same. We have to show we're willing to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I can't walk away. You can walk away, because you have nothing to lose, because there's no one in your world but yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Chace goes to the door. As he leaves:  72.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seventeen million dollars and zero dollars. That's how far apart we are. Those numbers have got to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail lies in bed in the fetal position. The phone rings. She goes to the kitchen and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Seven million dollars. DIAL TONE. Gail is left holding the receiver. The numbers have just moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREAT SHAFTS OF LIGHT penetrate the darkness of the Basil vaulted dome. In a pew toward the rear Gail and Chace sit eight feet apart, like a couple waiting to get a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: When a man like you resorts to prayer I start to worry we're running out of options.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: We're not here to pray. We're here to speak to the Archbishop Marcinckus. The six-foot-six ARCHBISHOP MARCINCKUS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Otherwise known as the Pope's Gorilla.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Marcinkus and Gail with their heads bowed in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS/GAIL
dialogues.text: Sancta Maria, Mater Dei, ora pro nobis peccatoribus, nunc, et in hora mortis nostrae. Chace sits watching a few rows back, like a man waiting i bus station. As their prayers are finished, he joins them

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: Ms Getty, the Holy Pontiff himself is praying today for the safe return of your beautiful boy.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Archbishop Marcinkus. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was hoping you could use your personal influence to help Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Paul has been kidnapped by the N'dragheta, father. Marcinkus nods. He speaks in a blunt Chicago accent:

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: I may be able to have some influence there. (off Gail's look) Don't look so surprised. The Vatican has for hundreds of years had relationships with the ancient fraternal organizations of Italy.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Actually, we were hoping his Holiness would persuade my father-in-law to pay the ransom.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: You want me to ask the Pontiff to twist J Paul Getty's arm?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty tends to listen to those he considers his equals.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: And he thinks the Pope is his equal.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Nearly.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: You gave me the impression that you were here on Mr. Getty's behalf. Who is it you're working for? For a moment, Chace doesn't know how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I just want to bring the boy home. Marcinkus rises.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: I'll have a word with his Holiness. (re: Chace's face) You look like you met up with something that didn't agree with you.  74. Gail looks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Rome is a tough town, Father.

dialogues.speaker: MARCINKUS
dialogues.text: The toughest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail and Chace walk in the shade of the colonnades beside the vast plaza. Chace keeps his distance.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I owe you an apology, Mr Chace. I was angry, but that's no excuse.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I've taken worse beatings before for less cause. Never with a princess phone, though.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Please don't make a joke out of it.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: OK, how about this, then. You were right when you said I had nothing. I'm not important, I'm not rich.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: But if I had the money to give I'd give it to you. Gail looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me rephrase that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Don't. Gail walks through the colonnade, and Chace walks with he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRIVATE PLANE taxis on the mist-shrouded runway. The clamshell air-stair descends, a black sedan pulls up, and two bodyguards whisk J Paul Getty inside.  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty and his coterie enter via the alley door, briskly m through the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of furtive Milanese in black designer clothes hov outside a hotel suite.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Getty.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Nothing good about it. Let's get down to business.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Are you serious about making payment?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be here if I weren't.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Because there can't be any more games. You know our price, and it's not subject to negotiation any longer. Payment must be made in cash, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I want the proof first.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters, Getty is overcome with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: There you are. REVERSE ANGLE: there on the bedspread is a small painting Albrecht Diirer's 15th Century "Madonna and Child in a Wi

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Because of the painting's disputed provenance, it can never be publicly displayed. As discussed, our price is $1.15 million.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we weren't able to bring the full sum. Liquidity, you know. Otto motions for his men to begin packing up the painting  76.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: True masterpieces never go on sale, Mr. Getty. If you cannot pay, you will never own one. Getty grimaces. He turns to one of his coterie:

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Pay the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUTCHER cuts flesh from a lamb's flank with a cleaver, wraps it in wax paper, and hands it to Sgro and Cinquanta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A field of dried grain roils in the wind. A tumbledown clapboard shack stands at its center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits on a bare mattress, chained to the floor. Cinqu enters with an oil lantern and a covered plate.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I brought you something to warm you, Paolo. Something special for being a good boy. He sets down the plate. Two steaks, running with blood.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can I have some crackers?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: What do you want that for? I brought you this good tagliata. Come on, we eat it together. Paul takes a bite. It's hard to swallow.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's too much. I'll be sick.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Look at me, Paul. You must eat it all, no matter how long it takes. Make sure you keep it down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You bring me steak now? Why? The door opens and a man walks in carrying a doctor's bag The Doctor indicates for Paul to come to him.  77.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Do as he says. The Doctor examines Paul's ears. He shaves the hair aroun the ear with a straight razor, then swabs it with alcohol

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eat now. Keep eating. Ask me no questions, Paolo. You have to trust me. It's important. He offers a bite to the boy, as you would to a child.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll eat it. Just leave me alone and I'll eat it all, OK? The Doctor exits, his examination finished. Cinquanta lea the plate on the floor. Paul takes a bite of the steak.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: If I could, I'd take your place. Cinquanta turns and walks outside, leaving Paul alone. Pa spits out the morsel. He takes out the Bic pen and the bo of matches hidden inside the waistband of his pants. QUICK CUTS: Paul uses the steak knife to scrape the phosphorous off the match heads. He removes the ink tube from the pen and packs it with the phosphorous. He goes to work on the shackle that chains him to the bar floor, attacking the floorboards with the knife. He hears the VOICES of the men. He looks through a crack the wall. They're drinking and singing outside the farmho He pulls on the chain again, leaning into it. Finally it gives. He falls, the chain CLATTERING across the floor. THROUGH THE CRACK IN THE WALL: the men fall silent, then resume their carousing. Paul picks up the pen tube and ra it to his lips like a peashooter. He lights a match -- -- and the phosphorous packed inside CATCHES FIRE. It spa brilliantly, like a Roman candle. He aims it through the crack in the wall, then BLOWS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- LAUNCHING it into the field of dried, broken grain. Fo a moment it is a shooting star, and then it lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL'S EYE peers through the crack in the wall --  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as his Roman candle sputters amidst the cracked stalks then dies. The light in Paul's eye seems to die with it. Then the wind picks up. The embers begin to glow and scat the cracked wheat catches fire.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE ENTIRE FIELD IS ABLAZE. Paul climbs out of the wood shed with the broken chain slung over his shoulder. He disappears into the wheat field. The flames threaten to overtake the barn; the men from th house come running, desperate to rescue the boy inside. Paul runs through the wheat field as A WALL OF FLAME cons it. The wind whips the smoke into a black cloud behind hi We PULL BACK to gaze down upon the young boy as runs, the great field of fire spreading in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul runs toward the highway with the chain slung over hi neck. A pillar of smoke climbs into the sky in the distan A single CAR drives by. Paul tries to wave it down, but t driver speeds up to avoid him. Up ahead, he sees it: a CARABINERI POLICE CAR driving away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hey. Police. Police! Poliziotto! Paul runs into the highway, waving his arms.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Over here! Attenzione! A car horn BLARES: the driver nearly clips him -- -- but the RED TAILLIGHTS on the police car light up. The mustached CONSTABLE stops and climbs out of the car. As soon as the constable gets a glimpse of Paul's conditi he hurries over to him. The boy collapses into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire glows in the hearth. The Constable's WIFE, a stock Italian Mamma, stretches a blanket over Paul's shoulders. In the BG, the Constable phones in to report the boy's re

dialogues.speaker: MAMMA
dialogues.text: Povera bambino... cosi freddo...  79. She goes to the hearth and spoons out a plate of warm pol

dialogues.speaker: MAMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mangia. Paul takes a spoonful. As he eats, tears roll down his fa The Constable and his wife smile warmly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can I make a phone call? I want to call my mother. The old woman brings the telephone to the boy's side and hands him the receiver. With trembling hands, he dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON the phone as it RINGS. Gail turns on the tape recorder, then picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? (a beat) Mom, are you there?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's alright, Mom. I'm OK. I'm safe now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul talks with his mother, there's a KNOCK at the doo In the BG, the Constable goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm at the police station. I need you to come and get me. In the BG, several men enter and exchange greetings.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What police station? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I just want to come home. You don't know how close they came.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm coming to take you home. What police station are you at?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hold on, I'll ask. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Excuse me, where am I? Dove sono io? Behind him, A HAND REACHES INTO FRAME and presses down on the receiver cradle, gently hanging up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul? Paul -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TILT UP from the phone cradle along the length of the man's arm -- -- REVEALING that it is Saverio Mammoliti himself that ha hung up the phone. He reaches out to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: Give it here. Paul hands the receiver to Mammoliti, who hangs up. We PAN across the faces in the room: Mammoliti's men, alo with the Constable, his wife, and, to one side, Cinquanta Mammoliti offers his hand to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come now, Paul. There will be no more foolishness. The boy places a hand over the ear that's been shorn and cleaned, as if trying to protect it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come. Paul takes Mammoliti's hand. They walk out of the station hand-in-hand, into the street, where Mammoliti's car awai The rear door opens, they climb inside, and the Mercedes vanishes into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail stands frozen with the dead receiver in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The apartment is overrun by Squadra Mobile officers, incl Del Rovere and Corvo. The tape squeals as it rewinds, the  81.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I just want to come home. You don't know how close they came.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm coming to take you home. What police station are you at?

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: (listening on headphones ) Ascoltare. Pavimenti. Footsteps. Someone approaches --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, where am I? Dove sono io -- CLICK. The line goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Someone breaks the connection.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He was in a police station. Nothing could happen to him there, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: It could have been a bad connection. It's Italy. Nothing works right.

dialogues.speaker: CORVO
dialogues.text: No. Everything works differently.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He was safe. He said he was safe. He was in this room, just now, talking to me. He can't just be gone.

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Keep the line open. He'll call back. We will wait as long as it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire in the fields has burned itself out; ASHES dance the air like snowflakes. Paul rides in the backseat with Mammoliti. Cinquanta rides up front with Sgro.

dialogues.speaker: SGRO
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) I'm starting to see why they don't want their kid back. Maybe they'd pay us to keep him, or kill him.  82.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Don't blame the kid. You'd have done the same if you could have thought of it. Mammoliti gazes out the rear window.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI
dialogues.text: A big fire like this? It draws attention. Inspectors. Bribes to be paid. We budget for contingencies, but nothing like this. The farmhouse comes into view. The wooden shed is scorche but still standing. We pull up in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMMOLITI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are carrying costs. It's discipline, fiscal discipline. Either the family pays, or we must cut our losses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops are all gone. Only their overflowing ashtrays an coffee cups remain. Gail and Chace have been up all night Chace sits at the table, tie askew, helping Ariadne, Gail youngest, complete a word-search puzzle in a coloring boo as her other son watches television.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNE
dialogues.text: They always hide the words backwards.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You don't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I enjoy it. It's about my speed.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He's not going to call. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I don't have a home. I have a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (to Ariadne) Come here, darling. I'1l help you. The girl sits beside Gail. She turns to another puzzle -- maze -- as Chace reluctantly gathers his jacket to leave. Gail watches, mesmerized with exhaustion, as the point of the pencil slowly winds its way through the maze. Then:  83.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My God. How could I be so stupid. Gail leaps up from her chair and RUNS through the living room, down the hallway and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail throws open the closet, opening shoeboxes and flingi them aside. She reaches deep into the dark and finds it: THE MINOTAUR statuette lies inside, swathed in Gail's sca She closes the box and runs back down the hallway, past C

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Watch the kids.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to feed them? The door SLAMS behind her on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail fixes her makeup in a vanity mirror as her cab pulls outside the auction house. She pays the driver --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and grips the shoebox in both hands as she waits. An APPRAISER in a bespoke suit greets her.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to just show up like this.

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER
dialogues.text: No, Ms Getty, it is we that are sorry to keep you waiting. Prego.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: This piece came from my former father- in-law's personal collection. It was a gift to his grandson. By his own estimate it was worth $1.2 million, and that was years ago. The Appraiser opens the box... and the statue is unveiled

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My situation is urgent. Please, if you can give me any idea as to its true value -- The Appraiser's expression is one of surprise and confusi  84.

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER
dialogues.text: Signora, if we may have a moment alone to consult among ourselves. Gail nods and exits. Through the glass, we see him argue sotto voce with his associate. They call her back inside.

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seven or eight, at most.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (euphoric, relieved) Seven million -- !

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER
dialogues.text: No, Signora. Seven dollars. This is un gingillo, a trinket of the type sold to tourists. Gail's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: J Paul Getty is the foremost collector in the world. Do you really imagine that you know more than he does?

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER
dialogues.text: No, Signora, I do not. But I know what my eyes see.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (trembling) We're a joke to you. All of you. Me and my kids. We were never good enough. (gathering her things) I'll get another appraisal. Thank you for your time.

dialogues.speaker: APPRAISER
dialogues.text: Signora. You might start at the National Museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail walks through the Museum gallery clutching her shoeb showing the Minotaur to anyone who will listen. She final corners a DOCENT, who points her down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: DOCENT
dialogues.text: Dritto, poi a sinistra. Gail hurries down the corridor, then turns into  85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first it seems a cruel joke. But then she sees it, ben the cash register: AN ENTIRE BASKET OF MINOTAURS, dozens them, and every one is identical to hers. She kneels down before the wicker basket and reaches into it, touching them, hearing the chalky clink of the little idols as the other customers try not to stare. She quickl gathers up her shoebox and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out into the plaza, exhausted and overcome. As she reaches the center of the Plaza, she becomes dizzy. H steps falter, she hesitates... and then she collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOODEN STUMP is placed before us. It is dark with dried blood. The doctor's instruments are laid out upon it. Through the barn door we see Cinquanta pleading with Mamm through the Mercedes' rear window. The Mercedes drives aw Cinquanta enters. He offers Paul a bottle of cheap brandy

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Drink. Fast as you can swallow.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tastes awful.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When they get it, they'll pay, right? And then it's over.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: That's right. You'll be home soon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's only an ear, right? In the shadows, men are moving. A knife-glint in the dark

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: Look into my eyes, Paolo, always. No matter what happens. Don't look at anything else but me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Make it quick. Tell them.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: (to the Doctor) Un taglio, rapidamente. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Paul) Soon it's over.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When I get home -- A HAND reaches into frame and shoves a rag into Paul's mo OTHER HANDS grab Paul by the arms as he struggles. The do grabs the boy's ear, pulls it taut --

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Stabile! Tenerlo stabile! -- and begins to saw at it with a straight razor. Paul's eyes go wide with shock.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: At me! Look at me, Paul! My eyes! Paul's eyes are locked with Cinquanta's: they implore and accuse him. There is no blood; the ear is like rubber.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maria santissima! The doctor struggles with the knife. Then, all at once, t blood comes, spilling down the boy's face.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul -- ! Finally the ear comes free. They release Paul and he collapses, his blood spilling out across the floor, and w BLACK OUT.

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL YELLOW PACKAGE
dialogues.text: addressed to "La Stampa" newspaper is dumped out of a can postal worker's bag onto a conveyor belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW the little package as it drifts along on the ti of thousands of other letters and packages, passing throu chutes and sorters, until it reaches another conveyor -- -- where it abruptly STOPS. The conveyor belt is turned off; the hum of machinery goes silent. The postal workers leave their stations. The lights are switched off... .В».-and the package sits there on the conveyor belt, wai  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fletcher Chace is in Gail's kitchen, foraging through her refrigerator for sandwich fixings as her kids look on.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Look at this. We've got guanciale, pecorino moliterno, friggitello, scamorzina, Licini coppa, limonata. Back home you'd be stuck with peanut butter and marshmallow fluff.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNE
dialogues.text: I want marshmallow fluff. Chace starts fixing the sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: You're breaking my heart. I tell you what, I can get us some shipped from back home. I have connections. But don't tell your mother. Chace brings the sandwiches over to the kitchen table, wh is still burdened by the reel-to-reel tape recorder. He lifts it up and places it on the floor so they can eat.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More like it. Chace and the kids eat the meal he has prepared. For a mo Chace seems slightly surprised to find himself here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail collects the day's mail and the newspaper from the mailbox. From 0.S. we hear the sound of a camera CLICKING Gail looks up to see a weedy PAPARAZZO snapping pictures.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Lens cap. The Paparazzo removes his lens cap, embarrassed. He tries to get a reaction from her, calling out questions:

dialogues.speaker: PAPARAZZO
dialogues.text: Is your son dead, Signora? It's four months now. Surely he is dead.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAPARAZZO
dialogues.text: How do you know? Gail doesn't answer. The Paparazzo grows frustrated.  88.

dialogues.speaker: PAPARAZZO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We wait out here months. You don't pay the money. You don't cry. You don't care if your own son dies. (off her look) I have to earn a living.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Money's the best excuse there is. He shoves his cigarette in his mouth and climbs back onto his scooter, rewinding his film as he goes, then speeds a Chace stands in the doorway behind Gail.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure that was the last of them. They've all given up now.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Not everyone. A cold wind. She gathers her sweater around herself.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I wonder if it's cold where they're keeping him.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: He's a tough kid.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You've never even met him.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: It's what I'm banking on. (a beat) Look, I'm going to ask you a question, and you're going to tell me it's none of my business. But I have to ask. Who is Luigi Della Ratta?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You're resourceful enough to find that out on your own.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: To you, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Lou was company when I needed company. You know?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: It's all I've ever known.  89. Out in the street, some neighborhood kids are playing soc Cars zoom by at high speed, and the kids just play throug

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, kid, attento! Out of the street! The kids ignore him. Gail watches them.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: From the day you bring them home from the hospital, the world is full of dangers that were never there before. A penny lying on the floor. A lamp with a frayed electrical cable. A driver crosses the dividing line on the highway for an instant and all the light goes out of the world forever.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Hostages to fortune. (off her look) It's one of those things the old man used to say when he wanted to come off all sage and profound.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I've heard him say it too. I don't think he had any idea what it meant. Gail turns and heads back inside, leaving Chace alone.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Until now I don't think I had any idea myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SMALL YELLOW PACKAGE lies on the conveyor belt in the darkened Rome Post Office. The overhead fluorescents flic on, workers return to their stations -- -- and the conveyor belt comes to life. The little packag is borne up once again on the tide of letters and package

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ride with the package atop a MAIL CART as it travels through the bustling newsroom. It lands on a desk outside corner office with a placard that reads UFFICIO EDITORE. The Editor's SECRETARY slices open the package. She remov its plastic-wrapped contents. What is this? She looks inside the package again. No letter, no note. She shakes the yellow envelope and something falls out --  90. A POLAROID PHOTO. She examines the Polaroid in one hand, then looks at the plastic-wrapped object in the other... ...and SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail Getty opens the front door to her apartment. Once ag the street is teeming with reporters and paparazzi, all shouting for her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Gail and Chace through the newsroom, where the secretary's desk has been taped off by the Squadra Mobile

dialogues.speaker: DEL ROVERE
dialogues.text: Signora, it would be entirely understandable if you feel you cannot make the identification --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I have to see it. Just show it to me. Del Rovere nods to one of the uniformed police. Using a pair of tweezers, he pulls back the plastic wrapping -- -- to REVEAL a small piece of flesh in the shape of a que mark. Beside it a lock of auburn hair. The Polaroid lies face-down next to it. The policeman fli it over: it's Paul. Where his ear once was there is a fre wound. Gail inhales sharply and touches her ear.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's him. Gail gazes at the Polaroid as the Police bundle the evide Il Messaggero's mustached EDITOR appears at Gail's side.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: This must be a terrible strain.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He's alive.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Come, rest in my office, it's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail sits down on the sofa. Chace hangs back in the doorw The Secretary places a cup of coffee and cake before her.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I'm not hungry.  Gail looks 91.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: You must eat, Ms Getty. It will raise your spirits. around. There are several editors in the room.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I just need a moment to myself.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: I'm afraid time is of the essence.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Why? Do you know something?

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO EDITOR
dialogues.text: We would like to publish it, Ms. Getty. The photograph. Of the ear. (off her look) It's news. And we are a newspaper. The ear came to us. It frightened our secretary terribly.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's my son's ear. It's his. Ours.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: We want to offer some compensation.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't want to sell you pictures of my son's ear.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Your son is being held for ransom. You claim not to have any money. We may be able to make a negotiation.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: How much money are you offering?

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand American dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: In the eyes of the law, we own the photograph already.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Go to hell.  92.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Va bene. We will leave you alone now if you like. Enjoy the coffee. The editorial staff files out. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Pay me in newspapers. (off his look) I want my son's ear on the cover of your newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: We wouldn't have it any other way.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: But I don't want money. I want a thousand copies of your newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: And where would you like these thousand newspapers sent?

dialogues.speaker: A PALLET OF TABLOID NEWSPAPERS
dialogues.text: On every cover, the Polaroid image of the earless Paul Ge The pallet is RAISED on a forklift --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: -- and DROPPED in front of the iron gates. The forklift lumbers off, leaving the newspapers fluttering in the win

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There at the gate. What's that? The gates GROAN OPEN. Bullimore the butler steps outside. He pulls a copy of the newspaper from the pile and blanch Getty stands on the front steps of the house. Bullimore dutifully folds the newspaper and brings it to him.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's Paul. What's happened to his -- Then he realizes what he's looking at. Getty stands unsteadily on the steps. He HURLS the newspaper away from him. It comes apart in the wind. It becomes a swarm of paper, a swirling flock. They blow back upon him. Getty swings his arm to bat them away, the covers his face lest they peck out his eyes.  93. Getty turns and walks back up the great steps of his cast as the tabloid pages swirl at his feet. Bullimore remains on the steps to clean up what Getty has left in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Getty lies on his cot, pale and motionless, as Cinqu cradles his bandaged head.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Paul is dying. He's lost so much blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tape recorder rolls as Gail leans against the wall of her kitchen with the phone in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They wanted to take the foot and I convinced them to take the ear. But the foot is coming next. I hear them talking. I beg you, get the money.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Tell us where you are. We'll make a deal in exchange for your cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (laughs) The police?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We can get you out of Italy.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't understand. I can never talk to the police. It's onore. It's forbidden. Even if this was my own child.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There must be something you can do.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: What about you, Signora? I've risked my throat for your son. What have you given for him? Don't tell me you don't have the money. What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: I --
dialogues.text: The line goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinquanta holds the dead receiver. As he searches the coi slot for change, he sees a man in the square watching him He hangs up, walks out of the phone booth, and steals awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail places the receiver back in the cradle. Then it RING She picks it up again.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ms. Getty? This is Oswald Hinge in Los Angeles. I'm sure you don't remember me.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I haven't forgotten a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty's attorney sits overlooking the smog of Los Angeles

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: I'm calling on behalf of Mr. Getty. Not your former husband --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The old one with the money.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's the one.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Mr. Hinge?

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Getty has decided to pay Paul's ransom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail's eyes widen; she has to take a breath. Suddenly everything's changed.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: That's -- Thank you, Mr. Hinge.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank him. I am but a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I would if he'd let me.  95.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: You'll get your chance. We'll need you to come to Los Angeles for discussions. Gail's euphoria fades ever so slightly.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What is there to discuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail gazes through the porthole window at the grid of dir streets that extends unto the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, we are now beginning our final descent. The plane touches down with that abrupt SCREECH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail walks down a corridor, flanked by Fletcher Chace and Giovanni Iacovoni, her attorney. We round a corner and en

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty sits at the head of the table, as he did years befo He seems weaker following his experience on the steps of mansion. To his left sits Oswald Hinge, and to his right

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul? -- sits Gail's ex-husband, John Paul II. He is almost unrecognizable: gaunt, feeble, attended by a professional caregiver, a lost junkie in a borrowed suit.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that you, Paul? Her ex-husband utters a listless grunt. At the head of th table, the old man turns his lidded gaze to Fletcher Chac

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: Mr. Chace -- ? Chace walks to Getty's end of the table, where he takes h place by his employer. Gail is taken aback, betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be happy to know there are some new developments that will enable us to finally help our little Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: My tax attorneys have discovered that while ransom payments are not deductible under the tax code, I can write off the interest if I loan the ransom money to my son.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You've discovered that you can take my son's kidnapping as a tax deduction. (covering) I'm glad. I'm happy it works out financially for you.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: I think we can all agree that the most important thing is getting Paul home safely. And soon.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Soon, yes, aS soon as we can, please.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: The loan documents are ready, and the funds are ready to be transferred.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Paul will be so grateful to his grandpa when he gets home. He loves you more than you know.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: And I love him.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: There's just the matter of the side letter. A lawyer slides a document across the table toward us.

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In exchange for Mr. Getty's making the loan, you agree to sign over full custody of all of your children, including Paul, to your ex-husband.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Sign over -- ?

dialogues.speaker: HINGE
dialogues.text: There is no provision for visitation. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HINGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All parental rights reside with Mr. Getty. Gail turns to her ex-husband.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Are you part of this? John Paul II doesn't answer: he stares vacantly into spac

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Iacovoni) They can't do this, can they?

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: My legal team is the best there is. If it wouldn't stand up in court they wouldn't have written it. (a beat) Take your time. Sleep on it. Have your attorney read it over.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't have time to sleep on it. My child is being held prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: There is that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I let you have the money back then. I didn't ask for anything but my kids. You just can't bear to leave anything on the table, can you? Getty doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Gail --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Give it to me. An attorney slides the document toward her, along with an ornate gold pen. There's a blank line for her signature. She stares at the pen in her hand as if in a trance:

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a beautiful pen.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: The best. And then, with a single stroke, Gail signs her children a  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail makes her way back to the elevators, trailed by Chac

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Gail, I swear I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Call Inspector Del Rovere. Tell him to set up the cash exchange through Cinquanta.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I never dreamed he'd pull this. Gail steps into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's time for you to do whatever it is he pays you to do. Let's hope you're half as good as everything else he's bought. The doors close and Gail is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail and Chace sit on the twin beds on either side of the phone, waiting for it to ring.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Look, Gail --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You don't need to explain. You don't work for me, or Paul. You work for Getty. I guess I forgot that.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I forgot it too.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We have a problem. Giovanni Iacovoni has set up a makeshift office at a tabl by the window. He rises and approaches them, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The contract you signed. The language of the document. It's hidden. (a beat) Getty has agreed to loan his son the ransom up to the amount that is tax deductible.  99.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: No. The phone starts RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: So I investigate. Under US tax code, only the first million is deductible. That's all they wired to us.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What is the ransom down to?

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Four. Down from seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We don't have four. We have one. A series of clicks as, back in Rome, the Italian Police s up the phone connection:

dialogues.speaker: SQUADRA MOBILE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Momento per favore. Then Cinquanta comes on the line:

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Meno male. It's almost over.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: What is Paul's condition?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He's not so good, but we can keep him alive a few days, long enough to make the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We may not have all of it.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All of what?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We only have a million.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: The number is four.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One is the new number.  100.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: One is one quarter of the ransom. For this they'll send one-quarter of your son. Tell me, which quarter do you want? Cinquanta pounds on the phone with his fist in frustratio

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You greedy animali. You're the worst criminals of all.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: I guess that makes you the victim, right? Tell me, did you hold the kid down so they could cut off his ear?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I did, yes. (a beat) Listen to me. I'm out now. I don't have any money to make from this anymore. But I don't want Paul to die. You have to go back and get Getty to pay --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: He can only pay for what he hasn't got. It's his sickness. He has to get something for his money and I have nothing left to give.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I'm begging you, Signora.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You're begging me?

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: I don't want it to end like this. They expect the money in 48 hours. They won't believe you when you say you don't have it. If they don't get every lira they'll kill him.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: You have to get me some time here. I'm fighting an empire.

dialogues.speaker: CINQUANTA
dialogues.text: You think you're the only one. Cinquanta hangs up the phone and vanishes into the dark.  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chace drives along the winding highway. Gail sits in the passenger seat, gazing at the churning sea outside her wi

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: This is it. He's building some sort of mansion out here on the ocean. Chace pulls into a gated drive. They step out of the car and approach the gates. Gail presses the buzzer by the ga

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I need to speak to him. She buzzes again and gets no reply.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: We can't stay here. They'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Let them.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: We have the million.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: For a million they'll kill him. They won't believe me when I say I don't have the rest of the money. Nobody believes me.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: There were never any guarantees.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Don't do that. It won't make it any easier when the time comes.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: We knew what we were up against.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Then why. Any of this.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: For me? A chance to ingratiate myself with the old man, so I could make myself into a cheap imitation of what he is. For you, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: A reason to live.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: The money would have bought a chance, maybe a window of opportunity to grab him. Maybe not even that.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: The money, the money. I can't bear to hear about the money anymore. She leans her head against the iron bars, her back to him

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This thing that's made beggars of us, rats in a maze, grubbing out our lives for -- what? Ink in some ledger. We'll kill and die for it, and none of it is real. Chace reaches out his hand to touch her. But then she tur

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks I have the money. Nobody believes me when I say I don't. Why am I arguing with them? Chace doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks I have the money. The newspapers, the kidnappers -- they all think I'm rich. Do you know what they call that? (a beat) Credit. (a beat) We announce that I have the ransom money. All four million. We make the exchange. You get your window.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: What happens when they find out the money's not all there?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: By that time, we either have Paul or we don't.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Now you're thinking like a Getty. POLICE CARS pull up on Pacific Coast Highway behind them.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: The cops do come running when you're a billionaire.  103.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU POLICE OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're trespassing on Getty property.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: We were just leaving, officer. We don't need him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wears Gail Getty applies lipstick in a compact mirror. a designer dress, makeup, jewelry: she looks like Grace K

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I'm saving the receipts so I can return it all to Dior tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: IACOVONI
dialogues.text: Pit bella. In all my life have never seen a woman so lovely. This isn't the effect she was after.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: You look rich. Beautifully rich.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: That's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail steps onto the terrace, where two dozen reporters an photographers await. She steps before the microphones.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Following a long and difficult negotiation with my son's kidnappers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his sun-streamed living room, J Paul Getty watches television as Bullimore hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- I have decided to meet their demands and pay the ransom in full. Getty's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY
dialogues.text: "I" have decided to pay? this? In full? What is Getty turns around in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: GETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get me Fletcher Chace.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic. Fletcher Chace swelters in his rented car. He checks the gas gauge -- the needle's bobbing on "E". There's a gas station up ahead. The cars are lined up sev deep at the pump. Chace pulls into the gas line and waits A GAS-STATION ATTENDANT walks outside with a placard. Dri climb out of their cars and start JEERING at the attendan Curious, Chace climbs out and watches as the attendant pl the sign on the pump: NO GAS. Chace smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
dialogues.text: Priceless. He climbs back in and pulls back onto the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car has stalled out by the roadside. Chace folds his sportcoat over his arm and puts out a thumb to hitch a ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GARDENER's old pickup truck pulls up and Chace climbs o

dialogues.speaker: CHACE
